lines.text: Listen to me, Jungle Woman!
Now, when the Baron arrives, entertain him - the same way you did Bernard Shaw and Professor Einstein.
You mean make the crumb my house guest?
Exactly! And don't forget, the Baron arrives tomorrow.
Then we'll have to work fast. I'll get a flock of beautiful girls to give him a real African welcome! Then we'll throw the biggest affair since the Boston Tea Party!
Jimmy - you're a genius.
You took the words right out of my mouth.

[Talking on the phone]
Oh, ain't that you, my little white dovie-dovie? How are ya?
Now listen to me you dirty, big black snake in the bush!
Hello, Mrs. Joan Crawford, Mr. Durante. No answer.
Harvey, we can't afford to mix with strangers.
If we only went with our friends, we'd be pretty lonesome.
I wonder who they are?
Oklahoma oil, new in Hollywood.
My name's Harvey Clemp. I'm the millionaire oil king from Clemp City, Oklahoma. This is my wife, Henrietta, the oil queen. Henrietta, this is Jake.
How do you do?
And now I'll ask one of Schrazan's guests to say a few words. Ladies and Gentlemen, Robert Young.

Greetings, Ladies and Gentlemen. Is this a party! You should see them pouring in with that whoopie look in their big blue eyes. Gorgeous girls! Brunettes, once were blondes. Blondes that were once brunettes. Hello. And here comes a little Platinum. Hello Benzie! That was a girl, not a man. Hello doll. Oh, is she a dream and you should see that dream walking!
This may be madness to you Harvey Clemp, but it's bologna to me.
Henrietta you astound me. Why the place is littered with movie stars. And that makes some litter.
You know, there's something about you I like.
Sure it isn't yourself?
Ouch! You got me!
Oh, I think you'll recover.
If you'll nurse me back to life.
Plenty of fresh air and sunshine.
And moonshine!
Mr. Durante is in conference. He's not to be disturbed.
Well listen here, I want to see that pelican face, see, and I'm gonna disturb him!
But, the scientific gentlemen are with him. They're having their usual Wednesday night discussion.
Get outta my way, you big telegraph pole!

[Dreaming he is Adam in the Garden of Eden]
One, two, three, four, five. There's a rib missing. They promised me a woman for that rib. There's something screwy around here. Where's that beautiful baby doll?

[Enters Eve sporting a large schnoz]
Oh, Daddy!
A carbon copy! I've been ribbed!
Here's where you come in. Get busy with Mrs. Clemp. Do your stuff!
You mean, Don Juan?
You're better than Don Juan.
I'm Don Two.

[Doorbell rings]
I wonder who it is?
Maybe the Barrymores. Perhaps Garbo!
[Door opens to Laurel & Hardy]

[after Mrs. Clemp sings "I've Had My Moments"]
I'm gonna take ya under my wing and develop ya!
Do you think my personality and figure will appeal to the public?
You'll knock 'em for a ghoul, I tell ya! You'll be a double-feature.
Won't Clemp City be amazed. Maybe I'll be America's Sweetheart!
You'll be everybody's sweetheart! Your picture will be on every ash can.
My Dream Producer!
What's the matter?
You frightened me, honey. I was just dreamin'.
Why, you've been sleeping an hour. Come on. We'll be late for Lupe's party. Come on, dear.
Jeanne, tell me, do I look like a horse's head?
No, Jimmy. Not like a horse's - head. Come on, toots.

[Talking on the phone]
What's this you giving a party and not inviting me, huh? Answer me that.
Wait a minute. Wait a minute. You don't have to get sore just because I kicked you outta my last picture! You don't belong to these parties. You get too rough, too involved. Ha-cha!
Now, let me tell you something. The day I don't play in your pictures any more, Schnarzan will be terrible. What do you think of that, eh? Ha-ha-cha!
[Sticks her tongue out at Durante's photograph]
Beg pardon, we haven't met. I'm Harvey Clemp, the oil king. Look, a thousand-dollar bill.
[tears up the bill]
You can't do that unless you're a multimillionaire.
A millionaire! Somebody give him a slipper, quick. Elsie, move over, sit down,.
[to Harvey]
You eat, some champagne in the glass.
deliver the lions to the studio in the morning and get our check for fifty grand.
I will, thank you.
I'll give 60.
I'll make it 70.
Wait, you skipped 120.
Wait, gentlemen, you're going backwards. We was up to 130,000.
Go ahead anyway, I'll give you the 140.
I'll make it 150, and that's all that we can afford.
Can I hear 160, could I hear 155? Going, wenting, leaving, could I please hear 155? Going, going...
I'd rather make it 175.
Sold! Sold to the gentleman on my right for $175,000.
I want to congratulate you Baron, I think you made a mighty good sale there.

[Jimmy goes over to the screen]
Here mousy, mousy, mousy, mousy, mousy. Nice mousy, mousy, mousy, mousy.
[picks up Mickey]
It's Mickey Mouse!
[crowd responds with "Oh, Mickey Mouse."]
Hey you, let go of my tail.
[Mickey pulls his tail out of Jimmy's hand, does a Jimmy Durante imitation]
Ha-cha-cha-cha-cha-cha.
An impostor, stealing my stuff!
How mortifying, how mortifying!
The indignity of it, and a guest in my own domicile!
[Mickey punches Jimmy, laughs]
What impudence! My mansion ain't big enough for the both of us.
Okay pal, you wouldn't throw me out, would you?
I wouldn't, huh? Watch me.
[catches Mickey by the tail, and throws him to the other side of the screen, Mickey gives Jimmy a raspberry gesture]
Hiya, fellas.
Moe, what kept you?
I had to work overtime. How are you doing?
Oh, great.
Got any autographs yet?
Yeah, I got a book full.

[turns to Curly]
And you?
If I get another one, I'll have two.
Well, don't worry about it, we'll have plenty before the night's over.
Oh, this is gonna be a big night.
Well, I've got a big book.
Any celebrities show up?
Yeah, sure.
What are you, autograph hounds?
Yeah.
Did you get any?
Yeah, I got some.
Let me see.
I got a whole book full. Look at this, will ya?
[flips through the pages]
Look at that, look at that, look at that, look at that.
Them stars write fast, don't they?
Yeah.
Are you collecting autographs?
No, collecting photographs.
[the Stooges pose]
No, not of you crumbs.
Hey fellas, seen any prominent people? There's a lot of prominent people here.
neanderthal!
[takes reporter's cane and hits his head]
Who?
Andro-phobia.
[takes cane, hits reporter]
What?
Androgenes.
[takes cane, hits reporter]
No no no, Professor, your dissertation refutes every scientific theory.
But Doctor, please reflect on the profounder aspects of the matter and consider the vital points of my thesis.
But gentlemen, your theories are distinctly contradictory.
Are you guys actors or hillbillies?
Come out from under the spinach Gable, we know you.

[Moe pulls the professor's beard]
Yow-ow-ow!
Out of the way, morons. We are of the scientific world, not of Thespis.
[leaves]
a perfect specimen of the Neanderthal man.

[points at Curly]
What, that? Oh no, look at the measurements.
[examines Curly's head]
Look at that, look at that. Why, that's the androgynous type. I can prove it. The androgynous cranium is always hollow, now just listen.
[hits Curly on the head with the cane with a hollow "thud" ]
No, no, no, no, Professor, you're wrong.
[examines Curly's head]
That is the skull of the anthropedal.
No, that's more like the skull of the anthropedia.
[examines Moe]
Listen.
[hits Moe's head with his cane, with a "bonk", turns to Larry]
Ah, the obvious Neanderthal type, now.
[hits Larry's head with his cane, making a "click"]
Neanderthal,
[hits Larry]
anthropedial,
[hits Moe]
androgynous.
[hits Curly]
Well, there you are.
Hey fellas, seen any prominent people? There's a lot of prominent people here.
neanderthal!
[hits reporter with cane, making a "ding" sound]
Who?
Andro-phobia.
[takes cane, hits reporter]
What?
Androgenes.
[takes cane, hits reporter]
What, are you kidding?
[gives Moe, Larry and Curly a sweeping slap with xylophone sound effects]
Hold it!
[takes a picture of Moe, Larry and Curly]
Okay.
[goes to the door, turns away after seeing the butler]
Heh-heh, I'll skip this joint.

[Ollie rings the doorbell]
What do you want?
We'd like to see the Baron - Baron Munchausen.
What's your business?
he bought some lions from us and uh, paid us with a check.
Yes, sir, we've been all over town trying to cash it.
[Ollie searches his pockets, while Stan takes the check from his own coat]

[Ollie takes the check from Stan and hands the check to the doorman]
50,000 tiddly-winks?
Yes sir, the Baron told us that a tiddly-wink was worth a dollar-and-a-half in his country.
That is, you understand, at the present rate of exchange.
[Ollie twiddles his tie and chuckles]
You guys are screwy!
[the doorman re-enters the mansion, closing the door]

[Ollie folds the check and puts it in his pocket, ringing the doorbell again]
Now listen, if you guys ring that bell again, I'll break your arm off and stuff it down your throat!
Heh heh heh heh, hmph.

[Ollie rings the doorbell once more; the doorman rips a chime off the wall and goes to the door]
Who rang the bell?
I did.
[Doorman hits Ollie on the head with a chime]
Oooh! Ooh, mmph, mmph.
[Stan touches Ollie's head to stop the ringing]
Oooh! Ugh.
Are you going to stand for that?
I should say not. He can't bluff me; I'm going to see the Baron if I have to stay here all night. We'll give him his check and take back our lions.
That's a good idea. We can get along without his old piddly-winks.
Why, certainly.
We don't want his...
Not piddly-winks, tiddly-winks.
[Ollie glances toward the camera, does a double take]
"Piddly-winks"! Ummph!
